documents.t: This lesson covers fundamental concepts in ROS 2.
Gazebo is a powerful, open-source physics simulator for robotics. This module teaches you how to create realistic digital twins of robots and environments.

ROS 2 (Robot Operating System 2) is the modern middleware framework for building robotic applications. This chapter covers the essential concepts and tools needed to develop distributed robotic systems.

Gazebo is a powerful, open-source physics simulator for robotics. This module teaches you how to create realistic digital twins of robots and environments.
Duration: 5 lessons Prerequisites: Module 1 (ROS 2 Fundamentals) Skills: Physics simulation, digital twin creation, sensor simulation

Gazebo Basics: Installation and interface Physics Simulation: Bodies, joints, and forces Sensor Simulation: Cameras, LiDAR, IMU Digital Twins: Creating virtual robot models Integration with ROS 2: Sim-to-real workflows Performance Optimization: Simulation efficiency

By the end of this chapter, you will be able to: Set up Gazebo environments Create robot models with proper physics Simulate various sensors Build digital twins of real robots Integrate Gazebo with ROS 2 applications
Gazebo Version: Harmonic or newer Integration: ROS 2 Humble/Iron Languages: C++, Python, SDF/URDF Platforms: Ubuntu Linux
Start with Lesson 1: Gazebo Installation and Basics

ROS 2 (Robot Operating System 2) is the modern middleware framework for building robotic applications. This chapter covers the essential concepts and tools needed to develop distributed robotic systems.
Duration: 5 lessons Prerequisites: Basic programming knowledge Skills: Distributed systems, message passing, robot programming

ROS 2 Architecture: Core concepts and ecosystem Publisher-Subscriber Model: Asynchronous communication Services and Actions: Synchronous communication patterns Launch Systems: Starting multiple nodes Debugging and Visualization: Tools for development Advanced Concepts: Quality of Service, security, scaling

By the end of this chapter, you will be able to: Set up a ROS 2 development environment Create publishers and subscribers Implement ROS services and actions Debug distributed robotic systems Build multi-node robotic applications
OS: Ubuntu 22.04 LTS or newer ROS Version: ROS 2 Humble or Iron Languages: Python and C++ IDE: VS Code with ROS extensions
Start with Lesson 1: ROS 2 Installation and Setup

NVIDIA Isaac Sim is a robotics simulation and synthetic data generation platform built on Omniverse. It provides cutting-edge physics, rendering, and AI capabilities for digital twin development.
Duration: 5 lessons Prerequisites: Modules 1-2 (ROS 2 and Gazebo) Skills: Advanced simulation, RTX rendering, synthetic data, Isaac Gym

Isaac Sim Architecture: Omniverse platform integration Advanced Physics: High-fidelity simulation capabilities RTX Rendering: Photorealistic visualization Digital Asset Libraries: Pre-built robot models Synthetic Data Generation: Training AI models Isaac Gym: Reinforcement learning workflows

By the end of this chapter, you will be able to: Set up NVIDIA Isaac Sim environments Create high-fidelity digital twins Generate synthetic datasets Use Isaac Gym for robot learning Perform sim-to-real transfer Integrate with ROS 2 and AI frameworks
Isaac Sim Version: Latest (2023+) GPU: NVIDIA RTX or A100 recommended OS: Ubuntu 22.04 or Windows Integration: ROS 2, Isaac Gym, PyTorch
Start with Lesson 1: NVIDIA Isaac Sim Installation

Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models represent the frontier of embodied AI, enabling robots to understand visual scenes and natural language instructions to take physical actions.
Duration: 5 lessons Prerequisites: Modules 1-3 (ROS 2, Gazebo, Isaac Sim) Skills: Multimodal AI, foundation models, embodied reasoning

Multimodal Architectures: Vision transformers and language models Foundation Models for Robotics: Pre-trained models (OpenAI CLIP, others) Action Prediction: From vision-language to robot control Training and Fine-tuning: Adapting VLA models to robots Real-World Deployment: Deploying VLA models on robots Evaluation and Benchmarking: Assessing robot performance

By the end of this chapter, you will be able to: Understand VLA model architectures Use pre-trained vision-language models Fine-tune models for robotic tasks Design end-to-end learning pipelines Deploy VLA systems on physical robots Evaluate and improve robot performance
Frameworks: PyTorch, Hugging Face Transformers Models: CLIP, GPT-4V, Gato, and others Hardware: NVIDIA GPU (RTX 3090+, A100) Integration: ROS 2, Isaac Sim, real robots
Start with Lesson 1: Vision-Language Model Fundamentals

Welcome to the comprehensive textbook on Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics. This interactive textbook teaches embodied intelligence through practical examples, simulations, and vision-language models.
Robot Operating System 2 core concepts Publisher-subscriber messaging model Services and actions ROS tools and debugging Building robotic applications
Gazebo simulation environment setup Physics simulation and dynamics Creating digital twins of robots Sensor simulation Advanced rendering and visualization
NVIDIA's physics-based simulation RTX capabilities for realistic rendering Digital twins and digital assets Isaac Gym for reinforcement learning Real-to-sim and sim-to-real workflows
Multimodal AI models for robotics Vision transformers and foundation models Language grounding in robotics End-to-end learning with VLA models Deployment considerations

Sequential Learning: Chapters are designed to build upon each other Hands-On Examples: Each lesson includes practical code examples Interactive Queries: Use the chatbot to ask questions about any content Text Selection: Highlight any text and ask the AI assistant for clarification
ROS 2 Humble/Iron: Robotics middleware Gazebo: Physics simulation NVIDIA Isaac Sim: Advanced simulation platform Python/C++: Programming languages Vision-Language Models: Multimodal AI
Basic programming knowledge (Python or C++) Understanding of robotics concepts (optional) Linux experience (recommended)
Use the integrated chatbot (bottom-right corner) to: Ask questions about any lesson Get code examples Understand robotics concepts Search across the entire textbook Last Updated: November 2025
